definition: A complication that automatically adjusts for months with 30 or 31 days. You only need to reset it once a year (at the end of February).
Hour markers that are separate pieces attached to the dial, rather than being painted on.
Often used in forums when showing off a watch that has nothing to do with the current thread.
A mechanical watch that winds itself using a weighted rotor that spins as you move your wrist.
Also known as a hairspring; the tiny spring that allows the balance wheel to oscillate at a fixed frequency.
The cylindrical box containing the mainspring.
The difference in the duration of the 'tick' and the 'tock.' Ideally, it should be 0.0 ms.
The ring surrounding the watch crystal. Can be fixed, rotating (for diving), or tachymetric.
Steel that has been heated to roughly 290°C to create a deep blue protective oxide layer.
A watch only available at the brand’s official stores, not authorized dealers.
A plate fixed to the mainplate that holds the gears of the movement in place.
A specific movement model (e.g., the Omega Caliber 3861).
Hands with intricate metal latticework, resembling stained-glass windows.
An enamel technique where hollows are carved into the metal and filled with enamel.
A watch with a built-in stopwatch function.
A high-precision watch that has been tested and certified by an official body (like COSC).
A sophisticated, vertical-clutch component used in high-end chronographs for smoother button operation.
Any function on a watch beyond telling the time (e.g., date, moonphase, or minute repeater).
A decorative finishing technique featuring parallel 'Geneva Stripes.'
The knob on the side used to wind the watch or set the time.
A small magnifying lens on the crystal, usually over the date window.
Triangular, faceted hands that taper to a sharp point.
A folding metal buckle that allows a strap to open without being fully detached.
The measure of water resistance (e.g., 200m).
A transparent caseback (usually sapphire) that lets you see the movement.
A crystal that is curved on both the top and bottom to prevent dial distortion.
A simple, thin, elegant watch meant for formal wear.
A movement blank or partially assembled movement bought from a third party (like ETA or Sellita).
The part of the metal bracelet that attaches to the watch case.
The 'heartbeat' of the watch; the mechanism that regulates the release of energy from the mainspring.
Artificial aging (like tan-colored lume) applied to a new watch to make it look 'vintage.'
The decorative work done to a movement (polishing, bevelling, graining).
A chronograph that can be reset to zero and restarted with a single push of a button.
The speed at which the watch beats, usually measured in Vibrations Per Hour (VPH) or Hertz (Hz).
A dial finish that starts light in the center and darkens toward the edges.
A rubber or plastic ring used to seal the watch against water or dust.
A complication that allows the user to track a second (or third) time zone via a 24-hour hand.
The one watch an enthusiast wants above all others.
An enamel technique involving multiple firings at extremely high temperatures (800°C+).
An intricate, engine-turned decorative pattern on a dial.
A feature where the seconds hand stops when the crown is pulled out, allowing for precise time setting.
Small scratches on an acrylic crystal that can be buffed out with Polywatch.
The brand name for acrylic (plastic) crystals often found on vintage Speedmasters.
The pinnacle of watchmaking, involving hand-finishing and complex movements.
The study and measurement of time.
A movement designed and manufactured by the brand itself, rather than sourced from a supplier.
A shock protection system for the balance wheel.
A design where the bracelet flows directly into the case without traditional lugs.
Synthetic rubies used as bearings to reduce friction in a movement.
A complication where the hour is displayed in a window and 'jumps' to the next digit exactly at the hour mark.
The measure of gold purity (18k gold is standard for luxury watches).
A pocket watch movement where the seconds hand is in line with the winding stem.
A traditional unit of measurement for watch movements (1 ligne ≈ 2.25 mm).
The 'horns' on the case where the strap or bracelet is attached.
The distance from the tip of the top lug to the tip of the bottom lug.
Phosphorescent material (like Super-LumiNova) applied to hands and markers to glow in the dark.
The base plate on which all movement parts are mounted.
The coiled spring that provides the power for a mechanical watch.
A watch that must be wound by hand via the crown.
A small, independent watch company, often producing in small batches.
A small automatic winding rotor that is recessed into the movement to keep it thin.
A high-end complication that chimes the time using tiny hammers and gongs.
A complication that shows the current phase of the moon.
A one-piece nylon strap that passes under the watch case.
A non-magnetic alloy used for hairsprings.
The name given to Rolex’s water-resistant case design.
A proprietary quality mark used by Patek Philippe.
A finishing pattern of small, overlapping circles, usually on the mainplate.
A calendar that accounts for months of varying lengths and leap years until the year 2100.
The amount of time a watch will run after being fully wound.
